block.p: Telecom Start-Up Plans To Eliminate 2,000 Jobs Winstar Communications, which provides telephone and Internet service to 32,000 business customers nationwide, said that it would eliminate 2,000 jobs, or 43 percent of its work force, and halt expansion of its network.

During the economic slowdown, small carriers like Winstar have been buffeted by a struggle to raise money for expansion or even continued operations. And their weaknesses threaten to undermine even established communications equipment makers. [Page C2.]

Bankruptcy Overhaul Is in Danger A provision in five states that allows people to shield their homes from creditors is at the center of a debate that is threatening to derail a measure in Congress that would overhaul the nation's bankruptcy system. [A1.]

2 Companies to Sell Music on Yahoo Sony Music and Universal Music said that they planned to make their catalogs of music available by subscription over Yahoo. The two music companies, which operate a joint venture called Duet, said they planned to start the service this summer, allowing users to listen to songs online or possibly download them onto their computers. Shares of Yahoo rose $2.75, or 22.6 percent, to $15.25. [C4.]
Big Board to Trade 3 Amex Funds The New York Stock Exchange has decided to trade three exchange-traded funds that are listed on the American Stock Exchange. [C5.]

Standoff Worries U.S. Companies While American companies insist that the dispute between the United States and China need not damage commercial ties, a few are starting to say that the impasse could spill over into trade issues if it is not resolved quickly. [C3.]
Two Lawyers Charged in Fraud Case Two prominent lawyers were indicted on charges that they helped orchestrate an international stock fraud. [C3.]

Britain Reduces Interest Rates The Bank of England lowered short-term interest rates by a quarter point to offset the effects of a slowdown in the United States economy and sharp declines in world stock markets. [World Business, Section W.]

U.A.W. President Defends Daimler The president of the United Automobile Workers, Stephen P. Yokich, said that the 1998 merger of Chrysler with Daimler-Benz of Germany had saved Chrysler from extinction and that the union had a good working relationship with DaimlerChrysler. ''There wouldn't be a Chrysler today if there wasn't a Daimler with a fatter purse than we have with Chrysler in Michigan,'' Mr. Yokich said at a rare news conference. [C5.]

G.O.P. Lacks Votes for Full Tax Cut With final budget votes scheduled today, Republican leaders in the Senate conceded that they did not have the votes to pass President Bush's full $1.6 trillion tax cut. [A1.]

Governor Proposes Higher Rates Gov. Gray Davis of California dropped his opposition to higher electricity rates, proposing increases of up to 46 percent for the largest users and warning that only aggressive conservation and increased generating capacity could solve the long-term problem. [A12.]
The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission has begun an inquiry into the disclosure of documents in a case that involves accusations of abuse in California's natural gas market. [C5.]
